top_comment.text: is it bad to give your cat or kittens milk or people food ﻿
top_comment.author: Elaine Swanson

comments.text:
+teacherspet79 Kittens are supposed to be weaned between 6 and 8 weeks. (8 
is optimum from my experience). Giving a cat or kitten KMR (kitten milk 
replacer) after that time can actually be harmful to their digestive track. 
Also, @ Elaine Swanson :  Absolutely do NOT feed your cats anything dairy. 
This means no cheese, no cream, no milk, etc. Dairy is actually toxic to 
cats. A minor effect is runny feces, which seems harmless if you don't know 
what's going on. Diarrhea in any animal is usually a sign that their body 
cannot handle or process whatever caused the problem. Dairy can actually 
break down the digestive track slowly over time, causing more serious 
health risks further down the road.  Keep in mind that something not 
killing or making your cat seriously ill is not the same thing as that item 
being ok for your cat's health long-term. As for other "people food," I 
would suggest avoiding anything with preservatives, spices, artificial 
colors/flavors, and so on. Stick with clean proteins in the form of 
plain-cooked meats/fish. Some fruits and vegetables might be ok, but cats 
do not need these things in their diets. If you are ever unsure, there are 
a lot of resources online about what is and what is not safe for 
consumption by cats.
comments.author: Mariah Ames

comments.text:
there are products on the market for this, actually. there are several 
places in my area that carry kitten milk, which I use as a treat before 
bedtime for the kitten. I have to keep it away from the adult cat, because 
it tears up her tummy and she likes to sneak it, so bedtime just works best 
for us. look in your local pet stores or grocery stores in the pet food 
area and see if they carry it. :)

as for people food, I wouldn't recommend it. it's not made for their 
tummies and can make them sick or gain weight. not to mention, they learn 
that people food is okay, so you can't leave your plate unattended at any 
time. my girls don't touch food on the table because it doesn't appeal to 
them.
comments.author: teacherspet79

top_comment.text:
Jackson, I'm a big fan. I just finished your book, Cat Daddy, and learned a 
lot about cats and about you. Fantastic. My question has to do with what to 
feed my cat: you recommend a raw diet, but what about taurine? My Trina 
throws up commercial foods, so I feed her baby food--chicken variety, but a 
whole jar (which she gets in the day) is only 80 calories, and she's very 
petite at 8.5 pounds. I would give her a raw diet if I could rest assured 
that she is getting all the nutrients she needs, but is there any 
trustworthy direction on raw diets?﻿
top_comment.author: Cindylu001

comments.text:
As I frequently remind her, Trina is an indoor cat; and then I tell her she 
doesn't have to find a dry place to sleep when it rains or go hungry from 
no food or be afraid of dogs or other big animals that would fight with 
her. She usually settles down when she considers the alternative, but she 
sure would love to roam outside.  I agreed when I adopted her I would not 
let her outside or declaw her (as if I ever would do that!).  Trina was 
turned in twice in quick succession by owners who decided they did not want 
her, and she is slowly developing trust that this is her forever home and 
she is loved, but she doesn't want to be handled--no way is she a lap cat.  
She talks to me all day long but she doesn't want to be stroked. She'll sit 
near me no matter where I am but just don't put your hands on me! I'm just 
concerned because she only weighs 8.5 pounds and I can feel her hips when I 
do stroke her--I think she's too skinny, so the right food is imperative! 
She's picky about what she will eat.  I tried chicken livers but she threw 
them up and I was counseled by a raw meat provider that organ meats were a 
little challenging right now.  I've been giving her kosher ground chicken 
with her baby food, but she really wants the roast chicken I eat so I share 
it with her (no spices, just plain meat). This little girl doesn't seem to 
want raw food.
comments.author: Cindylu001

comments.text:
I'm not a cat expert but I've fed my cats raw food (rabbit, chicken, fish, 
etc) for a very long time and I've never had any problems with it. I would 
try chicken livers specifically because they're easy to find at the grocery 
and lots of cats love them! Is your cat indoor only?
Also I know it is probably not appealing, but feeder mice would work well 
if you're desperate. Many cats find food much more appealing live and you 
can rest assured they will have a full diet.
Good luck!
comments.author: Anna Sims

top_comment.text:
My cat won't eat anything but dry cat food
﻿
top_comment.author: Rick Konnagan

comments.text: My cat has a strange love for cheese. I don't know why
comments.author: Molly Jenner

comments.text: I love cats so playful do you agree

top_comment.text:
Yeah, I had a sneaking suspicision that crack was indeed in those temptaton 
treats.I mean, i have seen drug addicts and this is how they behave! So I 
will stop with the fatty kitty crack treats and find the protein they love. 
See ya at the May 1st hangout!Yaaaaay!﻿
top_comment.author: Lizzy Dee

comments.text: Yeah, subscribe to this channel, Dito!
comments.author: Lizzy Dee

comments.text: I love those adorable kittens lizzy! <3
comments.author: Dito Alvarez

top_comment.text:
I dont know what to do with my cat. when i got him he was a grazer (nuts 
left out for him all day then a bit of wet food in the morning and evening) 
i dont want him to be a grazer i want him to have meal times but no matter 
how hard we try he will only eat little bits and as a result i dont think 
he is eating enough. i take his daily allowance of food and split it into 3 
meals and he just wont eat it all. you would think he would be starving but 
he loses focus quarter way through and wont eat anymore. any advice ?﻿
top_comment.author: bec goesbananas

comments.text:
+bec goesbananas
Thats great to hear bec, glad the kitty is healthy and eating his fill haha
comments.author: Seshoo

comments.text:
+Seshoo He is eating me out of house and home lol. I just needed to find a 
food he really liked and once I did that he was golden. He munched through 
it so fast and his appetite grew. Now he will pretty much eat anything!
comments.author: bec goesbananas

comments.text:
How's the kitty doing? Well I hope. have you tried to play with your cat 
before meal times? It stimulates their predatory instincts, hunt, catch, 
kill, eat. You may find that if your cat has gone through this ritual at 
every meal time their appetite may increase and their energy is being 
directed in a positive direction making a more happy cat overall.
comments.author: Seshoo

comments.text:
Ask your vet how much your cat should be eating. I was very surprised when 
my vet told me to limit my girl to 1/2 cup of kibble a day (granted this 
was a high-protein high-fat kibble). The instructions on the bag 
recommended feeding much more. You should also feed her a grain-free brand 
that is very low in carbohydrates (there is a brand comparison chart of 
carbs levels floating around the internet so search for it). Once you know 
how much to feed, measure the food you put in her dish for free feeding. 
This will allow you to see how much she is eating. You also should weigh 
him so you can to monitor any weight loss or gain. Like you I tried to put 
my kibble eater on meal times. I put down a third of her daily allowance 
and let her eat that as she wanted but she wasn't allowed to eat any more 
until the next meal time. She could eat less than what I put out but not 
more. This imposed some scheduling to her meal times. The next step was 
going to be to take away what was left of the second meal after one hour. 
After a trial of this I was going to remove what was left of another meal 
after an hour and so on. But then she got sick, her mouth became sore and 
she switched over to canned food for me. Hope things work out for you!
comments.author: Polar Bear Hero

comments.text:
We have an elderly Norwegian Forest Cat, and she doesn't do meals anymore. 
In fact, the more we put in her bowl, the less she eats. I've found that 
just putting a tiny amount in the bowl, and then doling out a little bit 
more when she's done with that, will get her to eat more at one sitting. 
Yes, it's time consuming, but it's the best way to get her to eat more. I 
do that with her about five times a day. She doesn't eat anywhere near what 
she used to, but after implementing this measure, the vet assures me that 
she eats enough to maintain her weight and health.

Most cats don't need the amount of food that manufacturers say they do. If 
he's not losing weight, he's fine.
comments.author: Jaimes

top_comment.text: How do you train your cat to scratch the scratching board...﻿
top_comment.author: sera gout

comments.text:
+TemeryN agree on the 'hard to make appealing' - but the 'get tall post' 
depends on the cat. Sera - Consider where and how your cat scratches, is 
she/he laying down and scratching in a cozy way (flat one preferable)... or 
is it more playful (where a standing one might work better). If it moves 
its ineffective (think of using your nail file if need be)... so take a 
second look. Once its effective (fastened+) or a new one bought... try 
catnip, a 'jackpot' or similar to draw the cat's attention to the 
scratching board (a cat is not a mind reader...). *s also possible to make 
your own scratching post with sasal rope (..) so... wish you luck.
comments.author: JunNights

comments.text:
You need to make the scratching post more appealing then your furniture. 
Those little flat cardboard things WILL NOT WORK, they will prefer your 
couch or chair (or whatever else because it stands still/doesn't move 
around/is stable). Get a tall post that won't move around when kitty really 
gets scratching/clawing and some spray on catnip to make it very attractive 
(I prefer the spray over the bits of catnip, no vacumming after), also get 
the "don't scratch here" spray (sorry don't know names/brands but your 
local pet store will know) to use on your funiture that you don't want used 
as a scratching post.  Hope this helps  =)
comments.author: TemeryN
